content.description:
A student prepares several solutions of known concentration and measures their absorbance in a <math alttext="1.0 centimeter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cuvette to generate the Beer-Lambert plot shown.

Another student uses the same solutions with a <math alttext="2.0 centimeter" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>2.0</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mtext>cm</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> cuvette.
content.question: Which of the following indicates how the second student's plot will differ from the plot of the first student?

choices.label: The slope will be doubled because the absorbance is doubled in the <math alttext="2.0 centimeter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cell.

The slope will be halved because half as much light gets through the <math alttext="2.0 centimeter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cell.

The slope will be doubled because the molar absorptivity is doubled in the <math alttext="2.0 centimeter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cuvette.

The slope will be halved because the molar absorptivity is halved in the <math alttext="2.0 centimeter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cuvette.

content.answer: The slope will be doubled because the absorbance is doubled in the <math alttext="2.0 centimeter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cell.

skill.text: 5.C: Explain the relationship between variables within an equation when one variable changes.
